args: Ohmigosh, it's been FOREVER!\nI did a double-take when I saw you, Sinoa!
How have you been? You're staying\nat that castle these days, right? Oh!\nHow go your experiments?!
S-slow down, Mary!\nOne question at a time, please!
Oops. Sorry! I'm just so excited to see you!
Okay, deep breaths, Mary. So, what brings\nyou here? I hear you're living in that castle\nin the Mistholt?
Y-yes, you heard right. I'm here on\nvacation with the others from the castle.
Same as me, then! I'm here on break, too.
The Institute sent me as a reward for my\nlatest round of experiments going so well.
Nothing beats turning off your brain\nand kicking back for a while.
My next project is even more complex than\nthe last, but I'm feeling ready for anything!
(She just breezes through everything I\nstruggle with, in the lab or on the beach.)
I'm just reminded of how amazing you\nare, Mary.
I got your letter. You made senior advisor.\nCongratulations.
Now, I should really be going.
No, I don't believe I will!\nI have nothing more to say, so—
Maybe YOU don't, but I do!
Please, Sinoa, stop! You look exhausted.\nLet's get you into the shade to rest.
What? Why do you say that?
You've run circles around me—\nboth in work and in play.
Now you're even taking care of me.\nThe role reversal really is complete.
Sinoa! You need to stop this self-defeating\nline of thought right now!
I could NEVER have gotten to where\nI am today without your mentoring.
I'm really, really grateful to you. Didn't you\nsee the last page of the paper I published?
The special thanks section, you mean?\nYes. You included my name.
It couldn't have been easy convincing them\nto let you list an expelled researcher.
You must have had to call in a lot of\nfavors. To the Institute, I am anathema.
Maybe so, but I'd do it again ten times\nover! That paper wasn't complete without\nthe name of the scholar I most admire!
Who else, Sinoa? I was always too shy to\nsay as much when we were working\ntogether at the Institute, but it's true.
You are the consummate scientist.\nMy admiration for you runs deep.
What?! But all my experiments\nend in failure—often explosively so!
Even now, I'm a disgrace. For all my effort,\nI still haven't made one measly little\nwormhole!
But that hasn't stopped you from\ncontinuing the work.
Because a true scientist never relents.
Heh... That's what I'm talking about.\nThat's what's so impressive about you.
Opening a man-made rift in space-time is\nthe holy grail of the field you're working in,\nas well as its most intractable challenge.
A handful of scholars have offered\narmchair theories, but most dismiss\nit as an outright fantasy.
You combined brilliant theoretical practice\nwith a stunning imagination and let every\nfailure fuel your next attempt.
To this day, I've never seen anything as\nradiant as the glimmer in your eyes when\nyou'd say, ＂This time, for sure!＂
Your drive taught me a profound lesson—\nthat a scientist's greatest asset is the\ntenacity to never give up!
I don't know if I'll ever be able to fully\nexpress how grateful I am for that.
The days I spent with you in the lab\nare what anchor me in my work today.\nThey form the very core of my being!
I went through failure after failure before\nfinally making my breakthrough, too.
But every time, I'd think of you, pick myself\nup, dust myself off, and get back to it.\nBecause I knew you would never give up!
Heh, sorry. Hearing myself say all this\naloud, I'm starting to feel super self-\nconscious, so I'm going to take off!
But the takeaway is this:\nI'm always in your corner, Sinoa.
And I know you're absolutely, positively\ngoing to succeed in realms that lesser\nresearchers can only dream of!
Mary... I had no idea she felt that way.
Hold on to my tenacity, she says...

You bet your beaker I will.
That's all I ever needed to do.
My resolve is once again firm—
I WILL create a wormhole!
Thank you for helping me\nfind my way again, Mary.
I'd started to lose sight of myself.\nBut never again!
I am Sinoa, and science is embedded\nin the core of my being—my very DNA!
